  • proof-by-refutation-1
  • View page source

proof-by-refutation-1

Definition

proof-by-refutation-1 is the inference-rule:

\[\left( \boldsymbol{\mathcal{H}} \: \textit{assume} \: \neg \boldsymbol{P}, \boldsymbol{P}, Inc\left( \boldsymbol{\mathcal{H}} \right) \right) \vdash \boldsymbol{P}\]
Where:

  • \(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{H}}\) is an hypothesis

  • \(\boldsymbol{P}\) is a formula-statement

In plain language, it consists in posing the hypothesis that a proposition \(\boldsymbol{P}\) is not true, refuting that hypothesis by proving \(\boldsymbol{P}\), inferring the inconsistency of that hypothesis from this contradiction, and finally inferring \(\boldsymbol{P}\).

Python implementation

This method should be overridden by specialized inference-rule classes to provide accurate proofs.

infer_formula(p_hypothesis=None, inc_hypothesis=None, echo=None)

Apply the proof-by-refutation-1 inference-rule and return the inferred-formula.

Parameters:

  • p_hypothesis – (mandatory) The \(\neg \mathbf{P}\) hypothesis.

  • inc_hypothesis – (mandatory) The proof of inconsistency of the \(\neg \mathbf{P}\) hypothesis \(Inc\left(\mathcal{H}\right)\) .

  • echo –

Returns:

The inferred formula: \(\mathbf{P}\) .

infer_statement(p_hypothesis=None, inc_hypothesis=None, nameset=None, ref=None, paragraph_header=None, subtitle=None, echo=None)

Apply the modus-ponens inference-rule and return the inferred-statement.

Parameters:

  • p_hypothesis – (mandatory) The implication statement.

  • inc_hypothesis – (mandatory) The p statement, proving that p is true in the current theory.

Returns:

An inferred-statement proving p in the current theory.
